**[English]()**

 • [한국어](/wiki/Cloak/ko "Cloak/ko")

 • [中文（中国大陆）‎](/wiki/Cloak/zh-CN "Cloak/zh-CN")

- *This article is about the type of armor. For the item referred to as simply a "cloak" in some variants, see [leather cloak](/wiki/Leather_cloak "Leather cloak").*

A **cloak** is a type of [armor](/wiki/Armor "Armor") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*, and is one of seven armor slots available to the [hero](/wiki/Hero "Hero") and certain [monsters](/wiki/Monster "Monster"). It is one of three torso armor slots, along with the [shirt](/wiki/Shirt "Shirt") and [body armor](/wiki/Body_armor "Body armor") (or suit).

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Description](#Description)
  - [1.1 Use by monsters](#Use_by_monsters)
- [2 List of cloaks](#List_of_cloaks)
- [3 Strategy](#Strategy)
- [4 History](#History)
- [5 Variants](#Variants)
  - [5.1 dNetHack](#dNetHack)
- [6 Encyclopedia entry](#Encyclopedia_entry)

## Description

A cloak is [worn](/wiki/Worn "Worn") over the body, covering any other armor worn on the torso, and is one of two primary sources of [magic cancellation](/wiki/Magic_cancellation "Magic cancellation"). The effects of a [scroll of destroy armor](/wiki/Scroll_of_destroy_armor "Scroll of destroy armor") or the [destroy armor](/wiki/Destroy_armor_\(monster_spell\) "Destroy armor (monster spell)") [monster spell](/wiki/Monster_spell "Monster spell") will always target a hero's worn cloak before any of the armor underneath it.

Worn cloaks protect armor underneath it from the effects of [erosion](/wiki/Erosion "Erosion"), including [rust traps](/wiki/Rust_trap "Rust trap") and the attacks of monsters such as [black puddings](/wiki/Black_pudding "Black pudding") and [rust monsters](/wiki/Rust_monster "Rust monster"). A [greased](/wiki/Greased "Greased") cloak additionally protects the wearer from [holding attacks](/wiki/Holding_attack "Holding attack") (including [drowning attacks](/wiki/Drowning_attack "Drowning attack")) by preventing the attacker from grasping them, though it has a chance to wear off with each prevented attack.

### Use by monsters

Any monster that can wear armor and is not too large for body armor will wear a cloak.

*The following information pertains to an upcoming version ([3.7.0](/wiki/3.7.0 "3.7.0")). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.*

Large monsters that can wear armor will wear a [mummy wrapping](/wiki/Mummy_wrapping "Mummy wrapping").

## List of cloaks

| Name                                                                                     | Cost | Weight | [AC](/wiki/Armor_class "Armor class") | Material | Effect                                                                                                               | [MC](/wiki/Magic_cancellation "Magic cancellation") | Appearance      |

| [alchemy smock](/wiki/Alchemy_smock "Alchemy smock")                                     | 50   | 10     | 1                                     | cloth    | [Poison](/wiki/Poison_resistance "Poison resistance") and [acid resistance](/wiki/Acid_resistance "Acid resistance") | 1                                                   | apron           |
| [cloak of invisibility](/wiki/Cloak_of_invisibility "Cloak of invisibility")             | 60   | 10     | 1                                     | cloth    | [Invisibility](/wiki/Invisibility "Invisibility")                                                                    | 1                                                   | *randomized*    |
| [cloak of magic resistance](/wiki/Cloak_of_magic_resistance "Cloak of magic resistance") | 60   | 10     | 1                                     | cloth    | [Magic resistance](/wiki/Magic_resistance "Magic resistance")                                                        | 1                                                   | *randomized*    |
| [elven cloak](/wiki/Elven_cloak "Elven cloak")                                           | 60   | 10     | 1                                     | cloth    | [Stealth](/wiki/Stealth "Stealth")                                                                                   | 1                                                   | faded pall      |
| [robe](/wiki/Robe "Robe")                                                                | 50   | 15     | 2                                     | cloth    | Spellcasting bonus                                                                                                   | 2                                                   |                 |
| [cloak of protection](/wiki/Cloak_of_protection "Cloak of protection")                   | 50   | 10     | 3                                     | cloth    | [Protection](/wiki/Protection "Protection")                                                                          | 3                                                   | *randomized*    |

Four cloaks have a [randomized appearance](/wiki/Randomized_appearance "Randomized appearance") that is shuffled among the following options at the start of each game: tattered cape, ornamental cope, opera cloak, and piece of cloth. Of those four cloaks, the cloak of magic resistance is the only one that does not [auto-identify](/wiki/Auto-identify "Auto-identify") at all when worn; the cloak of invisibility will not auto-identify if the wearer is already invisible when putting it on.

## Strategy

For characters that do not start the game with a cloak, any non-cursed cloak of at least +0 [enchantment](/wiki/Enchantment "Enchantment") is at least worth wearing in order to protect body armor; a worn cloak is also an extra layer of armor that a [foocubus](/wiki/Foocubus "Foocubus") has to remove, which can give the hero an extra opportunity to refuse. Even a mummy wrapping or dwarvish cloak is sufficient for this purpose - a mummy wrapping additionally provides heroes that are [invisible](/wiki/Invisible "Invisible") with a means of entering and leaving [shops](/wiki/Shop "Shop") as normal.

Through the early game an into the mid-game, an elven cloak is one of the more ideal cloaks to keep on hand: it grants [stealth](/wiki/Stealth "Stealth") while worn and can be safely [enchanted](/wiki/Scroll_of_enchant_armor "Scroll of enchant armor") to +7, making it worthwhile polyfodder to turn into a different desired cloak.

Popular cloaks for the late game and/or the [ascension run](/wiki/Ascension_run "Ascension run") include:

- Cloak of magic resistance: A source of [magic resistance](/wiki/Magic_resistance "Magic resistance") typically paired with [silver dragon scale mail](/wiki/Silver_dragon_scale_mail "Silver dragon scale mail") or another source of [reflection](/wiki/Reflection "Reflection").
- Cloak of protection: Typically used by character builds focused on maintaining MC3 as often as possible.
- Oilskin cloak: Blocks holding and drowning attacks from [giant eels](/wiki/Giant_eel "Giant eel") and similar monsters.
- Cloak of displacement: Causes hostile monsters to attack the hero's displaced image instead of them, making combat or escape somewhat easier.

## History

Cloaks are present as an armor slot in Hack for PDP-11, which is based on [Jay Fenlason's Hack](/wiki/Jay_Fenlason%27s_Hack "Jay Fenlason's Hack"), and appears in [Hack 1.0](/wiki/Hack_1.0 "Hack 1.0").

In [NetHack 3.4.3](/wiki/NetHack_3.4.3 "NetHack 3.4.3") and previous versions, including some variants based on those versions, some types of cloaks have different [MC](/wiki/Magic_cancellation_\(3.4.3\) "Magic cancellation (3.4.3)") values:

## Variants

### dNetHack

In [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack"), player [vampires](/wiki/Vampire_\(starting_race_in_dNetHack\) "Vampire (starting race in dNetHack)") get a +1 charisma boost for wearing an opera cloak.

## Encyclopedia entry

Cloaks are the universal outer garb of everyone who is not a Barbarian. It is hard to see why. They are open in front and require you at most times to use one hand to hold them shut. On horseback they leave the shirt-sleeved arms and most of the torso exposed to wind and Weather. The OMTs \[ Official Management Terms ] for Cloaks well express their difficulties. They are constantly \_swirling and dripping\_ and becoming \_heavy with water\_ in rainy Weather, \_entangling with trees\_ or \_swords\_, or needing to be \_pulled close around her/his shivering body\_. This seems to suggest they are less than practical for anyone on an arduous Tour.

\[ The Tough Guide to Fantasyland, by Diana Wynne Jones ]

Description

Worn cloaks protect armor underneath it from the effects of erosion, including rust traps and the attacks of monsters such as black puddings and rust monsters. A greased cloak additionally protects the wearer from holding attacks (including drowning attacks) by preventing the attacker from grasping them, though it has a chance to wear off with each prevented attack.

Any monster that can wear armor and is not too large for body armor will wear a cloak.

Of those four cloaks, the cloak of magic resistance is the only one that does not auto-identify at all when worn; the cloak of invisibility will not auto-identify if the wearer is already invisible when putting it on.
